thread.title: In memory of the Marquis de Lafayette in Savannah
thread.title_full: In memory of the Marquis de Lafayette in Savannah | savannahnow.com

author: Savannah Morning News
title: In memory of the Marquis de Lafayette in Savannah
text:
Photos Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Prince Jean of Orleans, Dauphin of France, tours the Owens-Thomas House with members of the Telfair Museum and the National Monuments Foundation. Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - A recreating of the painting of Marquis de Layfayette's speech from the Owens Thomas House with Prince Jean of Orleans as Layfayette and members of the National Monuments Foundation as his entourage. Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - People are positioned for a photo recreation of Marquis de Layfayette’s speech from the Owens Thomas House with Prince Jean of Orleans as Layfayette and members of the National Monuments Foundation as his entourage.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - A Savannah Pedal Tour vehicle passes by as a photo is being planned recreating Marquis de Layfayette's speech from the Owens-Thomas House with Prince Jean of Orleans as Layfayette and members of the National Monuments Foundation as his entourage. Back | Next Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Molly Taylor, Director of Development at the Telfair Museum, introduces her son to Prince Jean of Orleans, Dauphin of France. Back | Next Photos by Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News
Above, Molly Taylor, director of development at the Telfair Museum, introduces her son to Prince Jean of Orleans, Dauphin of France. Top, people are positioned for a photo recreation of Marquis de Lafayette’s speech from the Owens-Thomas House with Prince Jean of Orleans as Lafayette and members of the National Monuments Foundation as his entourage.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News- The sons of Molly Taylor, Director of Development at the Telfair Museum, play on the fence of the Owens-Thomas House as they wait for the Dauphin of France, Prince Jean of Orleans, to arrive. By Savannah Morning News I n 1825, the citizens of Savannah applauded the appearance of the Marquis de Lafayette — a hero of the American Revolution — as he waved from the balcony of the Owens-Thomas House at 124 Abercorn St. during a yearlong tour of the United States.
On Friday evening — 190 years later — Prince Jean of Orleans, the Dauphin of France, who was in Savannah to commemorate the siege of Savannah in 1779, stood on the balcony to re-create that historic moment on the part of his French countryman.
Prince Jean also took part in activities at Battlefield Park, where he paid tribute to an individual French soldier — Pierre Charles L’Enfant — who was severely wounded during the Oct. 9, 1779, battle and later gained fame as the designer of Washington, D.C.
Prince Jean’s visit to Savannah was part of a two-day schedule of events organized by the Millennium Gate Museum of Atlanta to mark the anniversary of the 1778 Franco-American Treaty of Alliance.
